documents.title: police chief and bbc questioned over cliff richard raid - summary
text: among the many misdeeds by the police in modern times , tipping off the bbc about the raid on sir cliff richard 's home must be fairly near the bottom of the pile .

in fact , you could argue that the decision to help a legitimate news organisation cover a legitimate story was not really a mistake at all although most people who watched the coverage ( i was on holiday abroad at the time ) seem to think it reflected poorly on south yorkshire police .
still , did poor david crompton , the south yorkshire chief constable , really deserve such a mauling ?

it 's keith vaz 's job to hold officials like crompton to account , and he generally he does it brilliantly , but the danger of being quite so theatrical in a case like this ( see 5.26pm ) is that it leaves little scope for heightened outrage when a force does something really awful ( like , for example , allow 1,400 girls to be sexually exploited . )

now i 've got that off my chest , here are the main points keith vaz , chair of the commons home affairs committee , told david crompton , south yorkshire 's chief constable , that his force showed gross lack of competence '' in its dealings with the bbc over the raid on sir cliff richard 's home .
crompton said his view was that the force had been naive '' .
crompton offered a partial apology to richard .
we had a job to do but i do apologise to sir cliff if we were insensitive about the way that we did that .
we had a job to do , and we have an investigation .
the problem is that investigation could never be done in a low-profile way because it was fatally compromised from the outset .
crompton claimed that south yorkshire police had to give the bbc details of the raid because otherwise the bbc would have run a story about the invesgtigation , putting it in jeopardy .
he said : we were placed in a very difficult position because of the original leak and the bbc came to us knowing everything that we knew , as far as the investigation was concerned .
my concern was that if we showed the bbc the door , the very clear impression which had been left with my staff in the media department was that they were likely to publish the story .
that would have impeded our investigation .
i 'm confident that we made the right decision in difficult and unusual circumstances .
he said what he learnt about the media during the leveson inquiry influenced his decision not to ask bbc executives to hold back the story .
i did not really have that much faith that we could trust it would n't be published .
you only have to look at leveson to find a number of examples that were core to that particular inquiry where the media decided to publish anyway .
that was something very much in my mind .
lord hall , the bbc 's director general , said the bbc would not have run the story if the police had said it would damage their investigation .
if he had said to us , or others in the bbc news operation , that broadcasting this story would in any way have damaged this investigation we would not have run it .
vaz said the bbc acted perfectly properly '' in this affair .
the bbc revealed that south yorkshire police sent them an aerial photography of the block of flats containing richard 's home , to ensure they got the right property , before the raid happened .
this is not entirely consistent with what crompton said in a letter to the select committee last month when he said the police told the bbc about the broad location '' of the raid .
the bbc and crompton have given conflicting accounts of what the bbc 's reporter , dan johnson , told south yorkshire police about the source of his tip about richard being under investigation .
crompton said johnson said the information came from operation yewtree , run by the metropolitan police .
the bbc said johnson did not tell the police anything about his source .
crompton said 12 new victims had come forward to south yorkshire police since the publication of last week 's report into the rotherham abuse scandal .
the home affairs committee will take evidence from crompton on this in detail next week .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .
who needs police commissioners when keith vaz is around to give chief constables hell ?
the hearing is now over , but it was a gruesome experience for david crompton , the south yorkshire police chief .
vaz specialises in high-handed scorn but rarely is he as withering as he was this afternoon .
i 'll post a summary shortly .

text: the home affairs committee is now taking evidence about the way the police cooperated with the bbc over the coverage of the raid on sir cliff richard 's home .
( richard , of course , strongly denies wrong-doing . )

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: theresa may , the home secretary , said that there could be a government inquiry into whether political correctness '' at rotherham council contributed to its failure to take child abuse allegations seriously .
she made the revelation while responding to an urgent question in the commons about rotherham .
she said : the secretary of state for communities and local government shares my concerns over the failings by rotherham council that have been identified .
this includes the inadequate scrutiny by councillors , institutionalised political correctness , the covering up of information and the failure to take action against gross misconduct .

he is minded to use his powers under the local government act 1999 to commission an independent inspection of the council 's compliance with its best value duty , with a particular focus on its corporate governance and service arrangements , and in parallel he is considering the implications of the report 's findings for all local authorities in england .
may has expressed doubts about the proposal to make reporting child abuse sus a legal obligation .
labour 's yvette cooper said mandatory reporting should be introduced .
may said the government was considering the idea .
but she expressed reservations .

i think it is important in looking at that that we properly look at the evidence of whether this actually is effective in terms of the protection of children , because the question that has been raised in some other countries is that what happens with mandatory reporting is that the number of reports goes up significantly , but many of those reports are actually not justified and what you do is you diminish the ability to deal with the serious reports and actually to protect children .
mark easton , the bbc 's home affairs editor , points out that the nspcc came out against mandatory reporting seven years ago .

mark easton ( @ bbcmarkeaston ) 'mandatory reporting is unlikely to lead to improvements in the protection of children ' @ twitterid 2007 keith vaz , the chair of the home affairs committee , has announced that shaun wright , the south yorkshire police and crime commissioner , will give evidence to his committee next week about the rotherham scandal .
wright is under pressure to resign because he was responsible for children and young people 's services at rotherham council from 2005 to 2010 .

the labour mp barry sheerman has said that he feels very guilty '' that he did not do more to tackle the abuse in rotherham , which he knew about , when he was chair of the commons education committee .
( see 1.22pm . )
may has said that the crown prosecution service is currently considering dropping the arrest warrant that has led to the arrest of ashya king 's parents in spain .
nick clegg has also questioned whether the full force of the law '' should be used against them , and david cameron has just now also said he would like to see them reunited with their son .

support for scottish independence has risen by eight points in the last month , in a poll described as a breakthrough '' by yes campaigners .
as katie allen reports in a separate story , this seems to have led to fall in the value of the pound .
analysts believed there was only a small chance of a yes victory but the poll on tuesday upset currency markets , raising the cost of hedging against sharp swings in the pound rise .

as investors sought to insure against the impact of a yes vote , one measure of hedging costs - implied volatility '' - looked on track for its biggest one-day rise for three years , according to reuters .
it quoted traders as saying that people were getting more jittery as referendum day approaches .

sir nicholas macpherson , the permanent secretary at the treasury , has told a committee of mps that , although the civil service is not making contingency plans for a yes vote in the scottish independence referendum , there are plans for contingency plans .
he said : there are plans and plans .

we may have made contingency plans about contingency plans , by which i mean if scotland were to vote for independence in the early hours of the morning - assuming we know by the early hours of the morning - we will have a team in place which will be tasked with dealing with this issue .
i think the governor of the bank of england is on record as having told this committee that he has some contingency plans .
i 'm confident that we will be ready to go .
the conservatives have announced that the clacton byelection , caused by the defection of douglas carswell to ukip , will take place on 9 october .
coincidentally , that 's david cameron 's 48th birthday .
speaking on the world at one , boris johnson confirmed that he would not stand in clacton .
he also said that he had received no serious approach '' from number 10 asking him to stand .
this is what he said when asked if he had been approached .
what i always do with this one is i explain that i do not go in to the conversations that i have with my friends and colleagues in government .
that general defence has served me very well .

but i 'll answer you , and i 'll say that generally speaking , that i had no serious approach to do it because i do n't think it would be the right thing for me to do given that i 've gone in for uxbridge .

johnson has launched a withering attack on the irrelevant '' and myo airports commission , after the panel set up to decide where to build additional runways in the south-east finally ruled out his plan for a new hub in the thames estuary .

he told the commons education committee : i 'm not a great believer in coincidence and i would find it very surprising if this was only happening in the few schools that we had the time and opportunity to look at in east birmingham .

some of the people who were involved in promulgating these techniques of gaining control and influence in schools have had national roles in various educational bodies and i know have lectured and taken part in conferences in other cities .

elizabeth truss , the environment secretary , has announced a pilot badger vaccination scheme to tackle bovine tb .
she announced it in a written ministerial statement ( pdf ) .
the [ badger edge vaccine scheme ] will support badger vaccination projects in areas next to the bovine tb high risk area .
the edge area covers counties in the middle of the country such as cheshire , oxfordshire and hampshire .
these areas are most at risk from the disease spreading from the south west and west midlands .
vaccinating healthy badgers in this way is intended to help create a buffer zone to help prevent the spread of bovine tb to new areas of the country where the incidence of btb is currently low .

may says she will look at this .
labour 's kevin barron , mp for rother valley , says he met one of the rotherham abuse victims and her family 10 years ago .
they were angry south yorkshire police would not investigate .
he supported them , but the police refused to meet him with the family .
may is responding to cooper .
the government is looking at mandatory reporting .
but it wants to be sure it will help children .
in other countries it leads to an increase in the number of cases being reported to the police .
but there is a danger this could lead to genuine cases being overlooked through lack of resources , she says .
it is a complicated issue .
may expressed doubts about a proposed law making reporting child abuse sus mandatory .
labour are demanding this , and may said she was considering it .
but it could prove counter-productive , she said .
may says the home office is looking into the allegations raised on panorama that it ignored reports of abuse in rotherham when labour was in office .
on the abuse inquiry , may says she hopes to announce the chair very soon '' .
but she has been taking her time , so as to be sure that the chair has the full confidence of the public .
on the police and crime commissioner , shaun wright , may says he is accountable to the electorate .
and she says labour chose him as their candidate for police and crime commissioner , even though he stood down as a councillor after the child abuse problems .
so cooper should think carefully '' before attacking may over this , she says .
yvette cooper , the shadow home secretary , is responding .
she says the report is damning '' .
it is never an excuse to turn a blind eye , or to say children consented in their abuse , she says .
she welcomes south yorkshire 's decision to hold an inquiry .
but why is n't it being supervised by the ippc ?
is may concerned the police commissioner has not stood down ?
and why is n't there anything in the legislation to allow this ?
and where is the over-arching inquiry ?
after two months , we still have no terms of reference and no chair , she says .
this is not just historic .
it is happening today , she says .
she says the law should be changed so that we have mandatory reporting ( ie , people would have a legal duty to report abuse sus yvette cooper parliament
theresa may is making her statement now .
( yvette cooper 's question was simply a request for a statement . )
may says the jay report reveals a complete dereliction of duty '' .
it makes for shocking reading '' .
some 1,400 children , on a conservative estimate , were sexually exploited .
she says she has spoken to south yorkshire police .
there are currently a number of ongoing investigations covering several hundred victims .
rotherham is just one of a number of cases , she says .
that is why the government is setting up an abuse inquiry .
later today may will meet professor jay to discuss her report , and how its findings can be fed into the inquiry .
the report raises a number of issues , demanding immediate action from rotherham in particular .
may says she will be chairing ministerial meetings on this .
they will consider what the government needs to do .
the government working group has already taken a number of practical steps .
for example , it has published new guidance for prosecutors .
training has been provided for security workers , to help them spot signs of exploitation .
a new victims ' code has been published .
may says jay 's report says co-located '' teams are an effective model .
eric pickles , the communities secretary , is minded to order an investigation into rotherham , and into whether it is complying with its best practice duty , she says .
may says cultural concerns , both the fear of being seen as racist and the frankly disdainful attitude to some of our most vulnerable children '' , should not prevent children being protected .
theresa may in the commons parliament
for reference , here is the rotherham child abuse report from alexis jay published last month .

documents.title: theresa may 's statement on the rotherham child abuse scandal
text: theresa may is replying to an urgent question about the rotherham child abuse scandal at 12.30pm .
i 'll be covering it in detail .

the labour party has suspended four members who held positions of authority at rotherham borough council during the years in which hundreds of young people were subjected to sex abuse in the town , the press association is reporting .
here 's an extract from its story .
labour 's ruling national executive committee ( nec ) has also taken control of a new rigorous '' procedure for selection of candidates to the local council in the south yorkshire town .

and the nec 's approval will be required for any application to rejoin the party by shaun wright , who quit labour following the publication of the jay report but has refused to step down as police and crime commissioner for south yorkshire , and former councillor maurice kirk .
in a statement , labour said : as ed miliband made clear last week , large numbers of young people in rotherham were systematically abused and then let down by those who should have protected them .
it can not be allowed to stand . ''

labour said it had instructed the party group on rotherham borough council to set up a scrutiny committee on child protection , including independent advisers , to help rebuild public confidence in the council .
it added : further action against others in positions of responsibility at the time may follow .
those responsible must be , and will be , held to account . ''
i 've got to go to a meeting now , i 'm afraid , and so i wo n't be updating the blog for the next two hours or so .
but i 'll be back again before lunch .

documents.title: boris johnson 's lbc phone-in - summary
text: here 's a summary of the key points from boris johnson 's lbc phone-in .
johnson insisted that his proposal for a new london airport in the thames estuary was still viable .

he described the decision of the airports commission to reject it as a very temporary setback '' and said that politicians should man up '' and accept the need for an imaginative solution to london 's airport capacity problem .
his idea was not dead , he said .
no , not at all , no more than , say , the channel tunnel was dead 100 years ' ago when it was first rejected .

he confirmed that he would not stand as the conservative candidate in clacton , where the party needs a candidate to take on douglas carswell , who has defected to ukip and who is fighting a byelection .
johnson said he had already applied for uxbridge .
the first objection to [ the idea he should stand in clacton ] , really , is that i already whacked in the cv for uxbridge .
it would seem a bit eccentric .
he did not mention the poll suggesting that carswell would win in clacton with 60 % of the vote , even if the tories ran johnson as their candidate .
he confirmed that he favoured removing british citizenship from britons who travel to a war zone without a good explanation .

the thing i called for , which nobody seems to have gone for yet but i think is perfectly sensible is , if you are going to go to that warzone , all you have to do is identify yourself to the authorities , say 'i 'm going for humanitarian purposes ' or whatever , explain what you 're going to do , people will say 'alright then , we ca n't stop you ' , then when you come back people will accept that .
but if you go and come back without giving any good reason at all , i think people are entitled to be sus i 've taken the quotes from politicshome .
boris johnson hosting his lbc phone-in
johnson is now pouring water over nick ferrari 's head as part of the ice bucket challenge .
and that 's it .
i 'll post a summary shortly .
q : germany has taken court action to ban uber , the internet taxi firm .
johnson says uber has been quite bumptious '' about launching in london .
his initial legal advice was that city hall could stop uber , because its charging mechanism did not count as a meter .
but there is now a legal challenge , he says .
q : what would you do to deal with the disruption hs2 will cause to uxbridge ?
johnson says he wants better protection from hs2 for west london .
q : what is the cash tube fare from city hall to uxbridge ?
johnson guesses : £ 4.50 ?
no , says nick ferrari .
johnson says you should use your oyster card .
then the fare would only be £ 5 .
a caller says london bus drivers are having to claim benefits because they are so badly paid .
johnson says he is not sure if that is the case .
he is not in favour of nationalising bus services , he says .
the british allow foreign companies to run transport services .
that would not happen in other countries .
can you imagine the french letting transport for london run bus services , he says .
nick ferrari plays various recording from the last four years of boris johnson ruling out standing for parliament while still london mayor .
ferrari accuses him of a tissue of deception , lies and deceit '' .
johnson says he said he would lead london out of recession .
q : what changed your mind ?
johnson says the economic climate changed .
there are now fewer neets in london than at any time in the last 25 years .
look at the olympic park and the regeneration in east london .
a massive amount '' of energy is coming from the government in london , he says .
johnson says , if lucky enough to be selected in uxbridge , he could be useful to londoners .

lbc ( @ lbc ) email question asks what boris would do with the ashya king case as pm # askboris lbc ( @ lbc ) boris on king : `` somebody is going to have to do some very , very lengthy explaining about what went down . ''

# askboris lbc ( @ lbc ) boris says howard davies is ruling out the estuary airport because he 's not getting support in whitehall # askboris ( i 'm posting the lbc tweets because i missed a section of the phone-in . )
johnson says he would have no problem with british jihadists losing their citizenship .
if people are going to a war zone for humanitarian reasons , they should say so .
otherwise , people are entitled to be sus ( this is the proposal he unveiled in his telegraph column last week for jihadists to lose their citizenship . )
johnson firms up his previous answer on tpims ; control orders are the way forward , he says .
q : what do you think of tpims ?
cameron says he agrees with the prime minister on this .
some way of geographically confining '' suspects would be a good idea , he says .
that is what the police are lobbying for .
( that sounds as if he is closer to david cameron than nick clegg on this .
see 9.02am .
but he was not very robust .
last week , in his telegraph column , he was calling for the return of control orders . )
q : what are you doing about tube security ?
johnson says he is getting more staff onto the platform .
the threat level has been raised , he says .
but that does not mean that there is a specific threat .
q : what about the idea that you should stand in clacton against douglas carswell ?
johnson says he has already applied for uxbridge .
nick ferrari challenges johnson to take part in a quiz about uxbridge , the seat where johnson is seeking to be selected as conservative candidate .
johnson refuses .
it would be presumptious , he says .
he has not been selected as a candidate .
ferrari gets him to take a call from uxbridge instead .
q : what would you do about anti-social behaviour in uxbridge ?
johnson says crime is going down across london .

documents.title: boris johnson 's lbc phone-in
text: boris johnson is now hosting his lbc phone-in .
the first question is about the airport commission 's decision to rule out the boris island '' thames estuary proposal .
johnson says he does not accept the idea is now dead .
howard davies has ruled it out because he thinks there is no political support for it , he says .
but politicians need to man up , he says .
he says there are many councillors in kent in favour of it .
city hall has spent a sum in the low millions working on the plan , he says .
it is a good use of money .

documents.title: nick clegg 's today interview - summary and analysis
text: yvette cooper has got a point .
following nick clegg 's interview , some aspects of the government 's security policy are looking even more confused '' this morning than they were yesterday .

clegg defended some of the measures announced by cameron , and he insisted that the new regulations for airlines were more significant than commentators realised , but he effectively rubbished one of number 10 's ideas , and subtly distanced himself from another .
here are the key points .
clegg seemed to concede that the plan to allow the authorities to stop suspect jihadists returning to the uk temporarily would never happen .
number 10 briefed this idea over the weekend , but by yesterday afternoon , when cameron delivered his statement , it has already become a rather fuzzy proposal , rather than a firm commitment .
here 's the text of cameron 's statement and this is what he said on this issue .
we are clear in principle that what we need is a targeted , discretionary power to allow us to exclude british nationals from the uk .
we will work up proposals on this basis with our agencies , in line with our international obligations , and discuss the details on a cross-party basis .
and here is what clegg said about this this morning .
at the moment it is not obvious what one can do in a way which is consistent with our legal obligations .
the prime minister , quite rightly , said we are not going to do anything which clashes with both our domestic and international legal principles and obligations .
clegg hinted that he was reluctant to allow relocation to be included in terrorism prevention and investigation measures ( tpims ) .
critics describe relocation ( a power that existed in control orders ) as tantamount to internal exile .
instead , tpims could be toughened just by greater use of exclusion measures ( which stop suspects from visiting certain places ) , he said .
you can either exclude people from going to places or you can move people to different places .
that is a means to an end moving people against their will from one part of the country to another when you ca n't prosecute them in court is a big step .
that 's why we are looking in government to see whether you can use , maximise and build upon the existing powers in tpims which is all about excluding people from particular areas .
cameron yesterday said that including relocation in tpims was an option .
clegg reaffirmed his support for the convention that , when possible , parliament should vote before britain gets involved in military action abroad .

documents.title: labour says coalition 's security policy 'utterly confused ' after clegg interview
text: yvette cooper , the shadow home secretary , says nick clegg 's inteview has made the government 's new anti-terror strategy even less clear .
yvette cooper ( @ yvettecoopermp ) utterly confused about what gov security policy now is # clegg @ twitterid4today .
why did pm make big claims at press conf if nothing 's worked out ?
nick robinson , the bbc 's political editor , is now giving his post-match commentary .
david cameron was vague to the point of waffleishness yesterday about the passport proposal , robinson says .
now clegg is confirming that this may be impossible .
that begs the question why downing street briefed the plan in the first place , he says .

robinson says it is striking , though , that both the conservatives and the lib dems rejected the idea of a sweeping overhaul of britain 's anti-terror law , as proposed , for example , by boris johnson .
i 'll post a summary of clegg shortly .
justin webb turns to free school meals .
pupils are returning to school this week , and clegg free school meals for infants policy is coming into force for the first time .
q : we interviewed a head saying giving free school meals to pupils who could afford to pay was a waste of money ?
clegg says this policy helps not just pupils from poor families , but pupils whose parents can afford to pay .
a pilot showed that pupils from all backgrounds performed better in schools providing free school meals .
a hot meal at lunchtime can have a dramatic effect .
it can make more difference than many other interventions , he says .
q : we 've had to borrow the money to pay for this ?
clegg says the government has not been a slouch '' at deficit reduction .
even though it is cutting spending , it should be investing in good programmes , he says .
this policy benefits all pupils , and encourages pupils to eat together at lunchtime .
and that 's it .
q : if we decided to join air strikes against isis , would parliament have to approve that ?
clegg says any british government seeking to get involved in conflict should seek parliament 's permission .
but cameron said yesterday that there might be times when that was not practical , for example if the government needed to act overnight .
but clegg says he thinks the convention that parliament is consulted is an important one .
q : how senior would a police officer have to be to confiscate a passport ?
and how long would that last ?
clegg says this would only be a temporary measure .
the details will be set out in the legislation .
he says he does not think this is controversial .
there are already powers to do this under the royal prerogative .
q : do you agree with david cameron that we need a power to allow the authorities to stop people returning to the uk if they have been involved in jihadist activity ?
clegg says he supports the significant new power '' forcing airlines to hand over more information about passengers .
and people can be arrested if they have been involved in terrorism .
but cameron also said there had to be a discussion about stopping people arriving .
q : do you support the removal of passports ?
clegg says it is not immediately obvious how this can be done legally .
q : but there was briefing saying cameron would withdraw the citizenship of suspect terrorists returning to the uk .
will you let it happen ?
clegg says it is not a matter of his letting it happen .
it is about the government acting proportionately .
the government will legislate to give officers the right to remove passports temporarily at borders .
q : you seem to be saying it is unlikely that the government will take new powers to stop people getting on planes .
no , says clegg .
we are proposing new powers .
[ clegg and webb are at cross purposes here . ]
clegg says the government will not flout the rule of law .
i think we can square the circle , clegg says .

documents.title: nick clegg 's today interview
text: justin webb is interviewing nick clegg .
webb is going to start with yesterday 's anti-terror measures .
q : we used to have control orders .
they involved moving people around the country .
david anderson , the independent reviewer of terror legislation , favours changing tpims to allow this .
do you support that ?
clegg says anderson does not want a return to control orders .
but he does want the authorities to be able to disrupt the associations of people on tpims .
you can either move people ( relocation ) or stop them going to some places ( exclusion ) .
q : do you favour relocations ?
there is a debate about how you do this , says clegg .
tpims already allow exclusion .
this morning the airports commission has ruled out boris johnson 's plan for a new airport in the thames estuary .
the london mayor has already reacted angrily , and we 'll be hearing more from him when he hosts his lbc phone-in .
first , though , we 've got nick clegg on the today programme .
here 's the agenda for the day .
8.10am : nick clegg interviewed on the today programme .
9am : boris johnson hosts his lbc phone-in .

3.30pm : david crompton , chief constable of south yorkshire police and lord hall , director general of the bbc ( at 4.15pm ) give evidence to the commons home affairs committee about the bbc 's coverage of the raid on sir cliff richard 's home .

as usual , i will also be flagging up any breaking political news , posting summaries with a round-up of all the day 's developments , and highlighting the most interesting political articles on the web , although i have got a meeting at hq this morning , and so i 'm afraid the blog will be quiet for around a couple of hours after 10.30am .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .
